facts.text: Village Kotheri in Taluka Mahal, District Kolaba is a Khoti village of Pat leasehold; appellants had a Khoti share of Rs. 0-12-1 1/3 in the village.

On October 9, 1950, appellants made an application before the Collector of Kolaba for compensation for Khoti rights in respect of reserved forest and unassessed lands under Bombay Khoti Abolition Act, 1949; claimed Rs. 17,615/- for entire village, their share Rs. 13,333-9-0, plus Rs. 7,480/- for loss under reserved forest (74 acres 32 gunthas) and Rs. 6,850/- for one-third share of trees.
Bombay Khoti Abolition Act, 1949 (Act No. VI of 1950) came into force with effect from April 12, 1959.

On January 31, 1962, appellants filed preliminary statement before Special Deputy Collector, Kolaba, contending Khots guarded forest in proprietary rights since 1860 A.D., land taken as reserved forest; claimed partnership with State in forest income, which subsists post-Act.
On May 15, 1962, Special Deputy Collector, Khoti, Kolaba made award granting Rs. 837.94 as compensation.
Appellants preferred appeal to Maharashtra Revenue Tribunal in Revenue Appeal No. 40 of 1962.
On September 16, 1963, appellants submitted written arguments to Tribunal.
On September 18, 1964, November 21, 1964 and February 1, 1965, appellants filed supplementary arguments before Tribunal.

On February 25, 1965, Maharashtra Revenue Tribunal set aside award, remanded for retrial stating points for decision: whether appellants prove proprietary rights in village/reserved forest lands, entitlement to compensation for gaothan/river/nalla lands as proprietors, customary share in forest revenues, market value thereof.
Act amended by Maharashtra Act 43 of 1963 providing compensation for loss of share in forest revenue, effective October 6, 1963, claims up to March 31, 1964.
Sud of 1869 at p. 124-A referred to by appellants regarding Khalsa and Varkas.
Survey plots 130 and 132 of Mauza Kotheri in dispute.

legal_issues.text: Whether appellants prove proprietary rights in lands of village Kotheri or reserved forest attached thereto, entitling them to compensation under s.12 of Bombay Khoti Abolition Act, 1949.
Whether appellants entitled to compensation for gaothan lands, lands under rivers and nallas as proprietors.
Whether appellants entitled as customary incident of Khoti to share in forest revenues of village, and market value thereof.

petitioner_arguments.text: Appellants had proprietary rights in survey plots 130 and 132 as Khots; Sud of 1869 shows bearing on claim; Khots had partnership with State in forest income which subsists post-Act.
Should be given opportunity to prove proprietary rights by oral and documentary evidence.
Act applies but compensation due for forest rights.

respondent_arguments.text: Khoti in Kolaba has no proprietary rights in village or reserved forest without separate sanad or grant.

court_reasoning.text: Khotis in Kolaba are hereditary farmers of land revenue, entitled to hold villages on annual customary kabulayat; no proprietary right in soil absent sanad/grant.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Khots have hereditary right to farm revenue, not property in soil.

court_reasoning.text: Right to trees vests in Government under s.41 Land Revenue Code unless express grant; presumption forests belong to Government unless displaced.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No proprietary right in uncultivated/forest land without proof.

court_reasoning.text: Tribunal correctly remanded; opportunity to adduce evidence on points; no concluded opinion on Sud of 1869 yet.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Affirm remand for evidence on proprietary rights, forest share etc.

holdings.text: Khots in Kolaba have no proprietary rights over soil/forest absent sanad/grant; rights to trees vest in Government.
Affirm Tribunal's remand order; direct Special Deputy Collector to allow evidence and decide per law in judgment.

precedents_cited.relevance: Khots have no proprietary right in soil but hereditary right to farm revenue.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ganpati Gopal Risbud v. Secretary of State for India
precedents_cited.relevance: Khots in Kolaba are hereditary farmers of revenue on annual kabulayat; limited interest.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sadashiv Parshram Risbud v. Secretary of State for India
precedents_cited.relevance: Khots not entitled to full proceeds of trees on Varkas lands; limited to one-third per kabulayat.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kodoth Ambu Nair v. Secretary of State for India
precedents_cited.relevance: Presumption that forest tracts belong to Government unless displaced by evidence.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Khoti Abolition Act, 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Abolishes Khoti tenure; provides for compensation if rights extinguished; definitions of Khot, Khoti Khasgi land, Khoti land.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Forest Act, 1927
statutes_cited.relevance: Rights to reserved trees vest in Government.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Land Revenue Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Right to trees vests in Government except individual property.

statutes_cited.name: Land Acquisition Act, 1894
statutes_cited.relevance: Guide for compensation in other rights.

statutes_cited.name: Maharashtra Act 43 of 1963
statutes_cited.relevance: Amends Act for forest revenue share compensation.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, affirmed Maharashtra Revenue Tribunal's order dated February 25, 1965 setting aside the award and remanding for retrial; directed Special Deputy Collector to allow evidence on specified points and pronounce award per judgment.
outcome.relief_granted: Opportunity to adduce evidence on remand

key_quotes.text: khots in the district of Kolaba are hereditary farmers of the revenue and are entitled to hold their villages as Khoti on their entering every year into the customary kabulayat.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines nature of Khoti rights in Kolaba.

key_quotes.text: in the absence of a sanad or a deed or a grant granting proprietary rights over the soil a Khoti is not the proprietor of the lands constituted as reserved forest in the khoti village.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key holding on lack of proprietary rights.

key_quotes.text: Government proprietorship of all trees is the rule and private rights or proprietorship, if any, are merely exceptions to the rule.
key_quotes.speaker: court
